quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Punching above weight with polish
quotes.text: And I'm not saying don't move fast. Obviously you need to move fast in the early days, but make sure someone rereads your email so that it sounds good.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Balances the common “ship fast” mantra with a concrete quality-control step that increases credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Punching above weight with polish
quotes.text: If you have sample content, this is actually a big one, sample content for your productivity app as an example. Take the time to not have it be like Jane Doe 12 times in the name list.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Gives a specific, actionable example of how thoughtful defaults in product demos can signal care and competence.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Punching above weight with polish
quotes.text: Have it be references to your industry so that people are like, "Oh, hey. That's a joke about Steve Jobs. I'm a designer. This person is thinking about me."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Shows a practical personalization tactic—industry-relevant details—that creates instant user affinity.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Punching above weight with polish
quotes.text: It's small stuff, but it tells that person, like, "The people who worked on this were thinking about me as a customer, they built it with me in mind, and that means that it is more likely that this is going to fit my needs than something generic."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Articulates the mental model that polish and specificity act as proof of customer empathy and product fit.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Punching above weight with polish
quotes.text: And frankly, when you are small, you need everyone rooting for you that you can possibly get.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that early-stage teams should optimize for trust and goodwill, not just speed.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Zoelle shares how to punch above your weight as a startup, the most effective and impactful growth and marketing tactics throughout Airtable's history, including their use of billboards, marketing investments that are often high ROI, and those that are rarely a good use of time, why PR and launches are actually useful to startups, and also when they aren't, and a lot more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets up a practitioner-focused menu of tactics and tradeoffs (e.g., billboards, ROI of marketing investments, and when PR/launches do or don’t work).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reminder to design onboarding/import flows for real-world messy inputs, not idealized data.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never ending sync for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden ongoing cost of “just build it” solutions—useful for build-vs-buy decisions in product infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of long-tail maintenance burden that can derail teams if underestimated.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like, "Error on line 53."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable UX insight: generic error messaging in critical flows (like imports) can block activation and adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers always seem to want to give you their data in the messiest possible CSV file.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (OneSchema)
quotes.context: A practical reminder to design data import flows for real-world messy inputs rather than idealized formats.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And building a spreadsheet importer becomes a never ending sync for your engineering and support resources.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden ongoing cost of maintaining importers, useful for build-vs-buy decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Six months later, you're fixing yet another date conversion edge case bug.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (OneSchema)
quotes.context: A concrete example of how edge cases accumulate over time in data ingestion, signaling the need for robust tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Customers get frustrated by useless messages like, "Error on line 53." And never end up getting started with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (OneSchema)
quotes.context: Actionable UX insight: poor error messaging in onboarding/import flows can directly prevent activation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Pando is disrupting the old paradigm of performance management, including a continuous employee-centric approach, so employees stay engaged, see their progression in real time, and know exactly when and how they can level up.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read (Pando)
quotes.context: A clear framework shift from periodic reviews to continuous, employee-centric performance management with real-time progression visibility.

quotes.topic_title: How Lenny and Zoelle first connected
quotes.text: Something that is pretty cool is that we actually met in my newsletter Slack community.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical community-led networking channel (a newsletter Slack) as a way to form high-leverage professional connections.

quotes.topic_title: How Lenny and Zoelle first connected
quotes.text: I actually looked this up of how we actually started chatting, and it was me cold DMing you to get a discount on Airtable for the newsletter subscribers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Shows a concrete, replicable tactic—cold DM with a specific value proposition (subscriber discount)—to initiate partnerships.

quotes.topic_title: How Lenny and Zoelle first connected
quotes.text: And you very happily got me that, hooked us up, and then you became a go-to Airtable person for advice on what Airtable did right and wrong over the years.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Illustrates how delivering a quick win can evolve into a long-term advisory relationship and trusted-expert positioning.

quotes.topic_title: How Lenny and Zoelle first connected
quotes.text: you're employee number 11.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a specific data point about Zoelle’s early-stage tenure, signaling firsthand experience with Airtable’s formative growth decisions.

quotes.topic_title: VaccinateCA: What it was and why
quotes.text: The federal and state systems didn't really exist yet, and so everything was this horrible hodgepodge, where eligibility depended on not only what state you were in, it was down to the county, and even sometimes the individual facility.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights the operational reality that policies and eligibility can fragment to the most local level, requiring ground-truth data collection rather than relying on centralized systems.

quotes.topic_title: VaccinateCA: What it was and why
quotes.text: And he had basically this really simple premise, which is, "If you call a pharmacist, and you ask them who they can give a vaccine to, and what vaccine they have, and then you put that answer on a map, someone else doesn't have to make the same phone call. And that takes lots of pressure also as a healthcare system and also helps people to match supply and demand."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A replicable playbook: reduce duplicated effort by turning one-off, high-friction information gathering into shared, structured, discoverable data.

quotes.topic_title: VaccinateCA: What it was and why
quotes.text: So surprisingly, somehow, that tweet, which is essentially like, "Call people, put in spreadsheet, put online," turned into an entire, full nonprofit that was mostly on Discord, Zoom, Airtable, and not only had this entire hundreds of volunteers who were making phone calls in the state of California and eventually, actually, nationally, we became Vaccinate The States eventually, we were also doing this thing called web banking.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Shows how lightweight tools and a simple workflow can scale into a high-impact organization when paired with volunteer coordination and clear execution loops.

quotes.topic_title: VaccinateCA: What it was and why
quotes.text: And eventually we had the most comprehensive database and map of locations in the entire country, including more comprehensive than the federal government and most of the states because they had really complicated limitations on what they could and couldn't publish based on some relationships they had. We didn't have those limitations.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson: a nimble, independent group can out-ship and out-inform official institutions when bureaucracy and constraints limit publication.

quotes.topic_title: VaccinateCA: What it was and why
quotes.text: So it meant that we became this clearing house, essentially, for this information and we built an API. We were working directly with Google. And if you ever looked up vaccine locations on Google Maps, that was us feeding that to them, which was really cool.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Demonstrates an impact multiplier: turning a dataset into an API enables distribution through major platforms and embeds your work into existing user workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer operations, Airtable backend, and impact
quotes.text: basically you had hundreds of people sitting there on phones calling vaccine locations, getting the specifics of who is able to get a vaccine there, and then just giving people a pointer of where they can get a vaccine.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable, low-tech operational model (distributed calling) to rapidly build a high-value dataset and direct users to action.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer operations, Airtable backend, and impact
quotes.text: ended up actually quitting my job at Airtable to work on it full-time.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example of committing fully when a project’s impact and urgency exceed what part-time support can deliver.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer operations, Airtable backend, and impact
quotes.text: it was a pretty incredible six months, where we filled a really critical gap in the infrastructure of the country.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Frames the work as identifying and filling an infrastructure gap—useful for practitioners looking for high-leverage problems to solve.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer operations, Airtable backend, and impact
quotes.text: We built an entire insane database, and then eventually custom software on top of that, to make the people who are making the phone calls more easily get the information in.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Actionable operations lesson: start with a robust data backbone, then layer workflow tooling to reduce friction for frontline contributors.

quotes.topic_title: Volunteer operations, Airtable backend, and impact
quotes.text: he was based in Israel, and he had had no trouble getting the vaccine whatsoever, but seen something on Twitter about it, and just decided he wanted to make sure that people were able to get the vaccine as easily as he did. And he spent dozens of hours calling folks, even though he was in a totally different time zone.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A specific example showing how mission-driven volunteer ops can recruit globally and operate asynchronously across time zones.

quotes.topic_title: Why VaccinateCA shut down after six months
quotes.text: We actually decided to shut it down after six months. Partially, that's because the existing system finally caught up.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example of intentionally sunsetting a project once the broader ecosystem no longer needs it.

quotes.topic_title: Why VaccinateCA shut down after six months
quotes.text: And frankly we didn't want to be in a place where we were pulling away resources that could be put towards other things that are going to be more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A resource-allocation principle: stop when your work is no longer the highest-leverage use of people’s time.

quotes.topic_title: Why VaccinateCA shut down after six months
quotes.text: We always saw ourselves as a stop gap, and once we got to the place where we felt like we weren't really being additive, we wanted to get people's time back, so they could work on other things.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A clear operating model for temporary initiatives: define your role as a stopgap and exit when marginal value drops.

quotes.topic_title: Why VaccinateCA shut down after six months
quotes.text: Yeah, I'd say probably three things. One, the incredible power of a simple idea to bring people together.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A repeatable lesson for mobilizing volunteers: simplicity can be the strongest coordination mechanism.

quotes.topic_title: Why VaccinateCA shut down after six months
quotes.text: Like, "Pick up phone, help save lives."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A memorable example of concise messaging that makes the action and impact immediately obvious.

quotes.topic_title: Three lessons from VaccinateCA experience
quotes.text: And combining those two things was an incredible way to bring a lot of people on board very quickly, because from a messaging perspective, messaging, something very important to me as a marketer, it was so concise. Like, "Pick up phone, help save lives."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Shows how a simple, concrete call-to-action can rapidly mobilize volunteers by making impact and individual agency obvious.

quotes.topic_title: Three lessons from VaccinateCA experience
quotes.text: I think in tech we often don't jump into these problems. This was not sophisticated technology. It was phones, Discord, and Airtable mostly being used like a spreadsheet. It wasn't anything wild. Even that very simple infrastructure was enough to make a huge difference.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that high-impact outcomes can come from basic tools when paired with the right system and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Three lessons from VaccinateCA experience
quotes.text: Number two, I would say just the importance of relentlessly repeating the exact same stuff over and over again, even if you feel like everyone definitely knows.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Actionable leadership guidance: repetition is a core operating mechanism for alignment in large, distributed groups.

quotes.topic_title: Three lessons from VaccinateCA experience
quotes.text: I think I repeated the same three talking points about why what we were doing mattered 5,000 times. Cannot overemphasize how many times I said the same stuff, and so did every other member of the board.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A vivid, specific example of “repeater-in-chief” leadership required to prevent misalignment and rumor-filling.

quotes.topic_title: Three lessons from VaccinateCA experience
quotes.text: People talk about it a lot, but it's never been driven home to me so much, because we're talking about something that had incredibly high stakes as people's health, and we're still able to do it in that context.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that high-stakes environments require heavy process/tooling, reinforcing the power of a tiny MVP even under pressure.

quotes.topic_title: Career overview and entering tech strategically
quotes.text: You can imagine in any community, there are nodes of influence, people who know a lot of folks, they have money, whatever it might be. And they're able to direct how that community or that ecosystem evolves.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A practical mental model for mapping power structures in an industry so you can navigate entry points and opportunities strategically.

quotes.topic_title: Career overview and entering tech strategically
quotes.text: And you can follow how they move between different companies, and who they worked with, and then see that influences who gets investment in the future. It influences the different partnerships that evolve. It influences the assumed wisdom in various different careers.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A methodology for tracking people-movement as a leading indicator of where capital, partnerships, and career narratives will concentrate.

quotes.topic_title: Career overview and entering tech strategically
quotes.text: And I ended up getting my start in tech basically by identifying a company where I thought I had a unique set of connections or understanding of the space that they were working in, where I thought I could maybe email the CEO and be helpful.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Actionable advice: pick a target where you have asymmetric value and use helpful outreach directly to decision-makers.

quotes.topic_title: Career overview and entering tech strategically
quotes.text: So I knew I wanted to find a smaller company, where they maybe were having more difficulty hiring, because they were less well known or a little bit less, I don't know, sexy. But while they were still connected into that broader group, because it has with a pedigree that people would take you seriously if you had worked at a YC backed startup.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career strategy: optimize for “underrated but high-signal” companies that are easier to break into yet confer strong credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Career overview and entering tech strategically
quotes.text: And the funny story on that is that I got that role by cold emailing the CEO while I was still in college.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example showing cold outreach can directly lead to early, high-leverage roles (employee one) even without a traditional background.

quotes.topic_title: From Box to Airtable: writing, comms, and growth
quotes.text: And the funny story on that is that I got that role by cold emailing the CEO while I was still in college.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example of proactively creating opportunities via cold outreach, even before having traditional credentials.

quotes.topic_title: From Box to Airtable: writing, comms, and growth
quotes.text: came back to it and wrote this ridiculous apology email, being like, "I promise I respond to emails faster. I see that you're hiring. Would you give me a second chance? Please, can I come work for you? I have no experience that's useful, but I work really hard."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Shows a practical, low-ego re-engagement tactic—owning mistakes and making a clear ask—to reopen a closed door.

quotes.topic_title: From Box to Airtable: writing, comms, and growth
quotes.text: So we were bringing over seven figure contracts. So I started developer success programs there.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A specific example of using revenue reality (seven-figure developer deals) to justify building a new function/program.

quotes.topic_title: From Box to Airtable: writing, comms, and growth
quotes.text: There was a little spicy, talking about some of the challenges, and I didn't tell anyone I was going to do it.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Illustrates a counterintuitive career lever: publishing candid work can create unexpected internal opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: From Box to Airtable: writing, comms, and growth
quotes.text: And I was like, "Oh, they're going to fire me. I went too far."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights the common fear around taking public stances—and sets up the lesson that the outcome can be the opposite of what you expect.

quotes.topic_title: Block Party: online safety product focus
quotes.text: Absolutely. We're an online safety company. We help users have more control over their digital experience. And our first product is anti-harassment and anti-spam tools for Twitter.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement that defines the mission (user control) and the initial wedge product (Twitter anti-harassment/anti-spam).

quotes.topic_title: Thread across roles: trust, brand, and product quality
quotes.text: And in my experience, people, and especially founders really underestimate how much every single touchpoint a customer has from word of mouth or the ad that brings them in the door, landing pages, signup flows, customer service experiences. Every single one of those moments is building a brand that is adding or removing trust.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat every customer interaction as a trust transaction that compounds (or erodes) brand strength.

quotes.topic_title: Thread across roles: trust, brand, and product quality
quotes.text: So for me in the early days, that means thinking about like, "What are the signals that I can provide to future customers that say, 'We understand you specifically, and our solution is designed for a person like you.' And two, that will say, 'Hey, we're actually operating on a much higher level than you might expect for a company of our size or our stage. We take this really seriously. We have all the things in place to take care of you. So you shouldn't be afraid to spend six figures or put your safety in our hands because we've got your back. We're doing this the right way.'"
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete two-part framework for “punching above your weight”: send signals of deep customer understanding and operational seriousness beyond your stage.

quotes.topic_title: Thread across roles: trust, brand, and product quality
quotes.text: Has tremendous dividends when you're in a business that is often driven by word of mouth. Because if you take care of people and you follow up that brand experience with a product experience that is really powerful and actually does the things that says it's going to do, then your word of mouth can become a huge driver of growth for the company.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Actionable growth loop: trust-building brand experience + product that delivers on promises = amplified word of mouth.

quotes.topic_title: Thread across roles: trust, brand, and product quality
quotes.text: So I remember really distinctly having to invite customers to go out to lunch with us when they would come to San Francisco back in the Airtable days, because we had 15 people in a teeny tiny office. It's not that I wanted to mislead anyone, but I didn't need to reinforce the fact that they were spending six figures with us when we had 15 people.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A counterintuitive early-stage tactic: manage “smallness” signals so they don’t undermine trust in high-stakes purchasing decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Punching above weight: polish, POV, and process
quotes.text: So those little bits of polish that don't take a ton of time are absolutely worth it.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A clear ROI claim that small, lightweight quality improvements can materially increase credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Punching above weight: polish, POV, and process
quotes.text: The last thing I would say is making sure that in your public communications launches, if you ever talk to press, which some companies can and some companies can't, having more of a point of view than just about your product, you can try and say, like, "We are part of something bigger. Here's the broader circle or movement that we are a part of."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A messaging framework for “punching above your weight” by anchoring your product in a broader trend or movement.

quotes.topic_title: Punching above weight: polish, POV, and process
quotes.text: One is you can have the founder that is the avatar of quality, who is just relentlessly being like, "Hey, we're going to do the 15 minute check. Yes, we're going through it. Yes, I'm going to send you a copy of this email, and someone else going to click every link in it, and make sure they're not broken."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A practical operating model: designate an “avatar of quality” and institutionalize a fast, repeatable QA pass.

quotes.topic_title: Punching above weight: polish, POV, and process
quotes.text: Also, just make yourself a checklist. It doesn't have to be complicated. "Every time we put out a blog post, these are the three things we're going to do. Every time we send out an email, it needs to be seen by at least one other person."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A lightweight process template teams can implement immediately to raise quality without slowing down.

quotes.topic_title: Punching above weight: polish, POV, and process
quotes.text: Take the time to not have it be like Jane Doe 12 times in the name list. Have it be references to your industry so that people are like, "Oh, hey. That's a joke about Steve Jobs. I'm a designer. This person is thinking about me."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example of using tailored sample content to signal customer empathy and build trust quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable billboards: signaling legitimacy to enterprises
quotes.text: They were actually super effective for us because we had a different goal than everyone thought that we did.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights the mental model that tactics should be judged against the true objective (e.g., credibility signaling), not conventional expectations like direct-response clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable billboards: signaling legitimacy to enterprises
quotes.text: For us, it was all about signaling to some very large companies that we were a legitimate and large enough company that they could trust, and we had geographical concentration in specific areas, because we were in the fashion industry, the media industry in New York, we knew exactly where all of their offices were and we knew if they saw our billboards, walking to work, and then got the request to IT for the budget in order to pay six figures for Airtable, they were more likely to be like, "Oh, it's not just some weird startup we never heard of." Like, "Oh, I've seen that billboard, they must be legitimate."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete example of using targeted offline presence as enterprise risk-reduction to improve odds of closing six-figure deals.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable billboards: signaling legitimacy to enterprises
quotes.text: We got mostly remnant inventory, which is at the end of a particular buying cycle. Sometimes they haven't fully sold everything, and you can get the slightly less good ones that are still maybe where you want them for really cheap.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: use remnant billboard inventory to get credibility-signaling placements at a steep discount.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable billboards: signaling legitimacy to enterprises
quotes.text: And everyone thinks that you only buy billboards if you're huge. So that small signaling thing was a way for us to make sure that we remove some of the risk of not being able to close deals because we were so small.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Counterintuitive insight that “looking big” can be a practical lever to reduce perceived vendor risk in enterprise sales.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable billboards: signaling legitimacy to enterprises
quotes.text: I would say you can expect that some of that inventory is in the low thousands of dollars, which is way lower than you might expect.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A useful cost anchor that makes the billboard signaling strategy feel accessible to smaller teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and Airtable growth tactics setup
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective, and I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete quality-control mechanism (high selectivity) that signals how to build a high-signal talent marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and Airtable growth tactics setup
quotes.text: I wouldn't say they were the highest ROI, but they're certainly one of the more interesting things that we did.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A reminder to separate “interesting/brand-building” tactics from highest-ROI channels when evaluating growth experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and Airtable growth tactics setup
quotes.text: The boring answer that I will caveat this with is that one of the pieces of our acquisition playbook, it was very standard, that did work quite well, was some unconventionally targeted Facebook ads.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights that even standard channels can outperform when paired with unconventional targeting—useful for practitioners designing acquisition tests.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and Airtable growth tactics setup
quotes.text: That era is over. So don't expect that that is going to work for your B2B business now because that that's totally changed.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A cautionary note about channel decay: tactics that once worked (e.g., Facebook ads for B2B) may no longer be viable today.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable acquisition: psychographic Facebook targeting
quotes.text: We spent a lot of time thinking about a psychographic profile for our users.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights a practical acquisition approach: define and target a psychographic persona when roles/titles are too broad.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable acquisition: psychographic Facebook targeting
quotes.text: Unfortunately, if you go out to the market with a message of, like, "Build your own software." The vast majority of people are like, "I want to do that. That sounds hard. That sounds stupid. No."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A counterintuitive messaging lesson: a product’s core capability can be a turnoff if it sounds like work or complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable acquisition: psychographic Facebook targeting
quotes.text: And this is a tinkerer persona, someone who likes new technology, they like putting together the Lego building blocks of things, and you couldn't really find Tinkerer's Magazine. There's not like a place those people hang out. They don't just have one title. It's a psychographic profile as a type of person that could have many, many different roles.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Defines a memorable persona framework and explains why psychographics can outperform title-based targeting for horizontal products.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable acquisition: psychographic Facebook targeting
quotes.text: But what you can do is you can say, "That type of person often likes these types of media. We've heard that they often are really into these podcasts, so they're really into reading about this type of personal development." And often that is associated with people who have these broad set of roles but have this typical mentality. So we would find clusters of interests that people might have, that often were shared by those people, and do targeting around that. And then when that worked, they'll look alike based on it.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Gives an actionable targeting method: infer a psychographic via interest clusters, then scale via lookalike audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable acquisition: psychographic Facebook targeting
quotes.text: No, and it's not a good idea anymore. Don't do it now.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A practical caveat for practitioners: tactics that worked in a prior platform era may be invalid after targeting/privacy changes.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable’s virality engine: champions and internal spread
quotes.text: The second set of things we were trying to achieve that's also useful context here, is although industry virality was really important for us, even more important was inside of company virality, that was the real superpower of Airtable. We'd go from 10 people to 1,000 people a year. And so we were always looking for ways to make that happen within companies in more and more efficient ways.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Highlights a clear growth prioritization: optimize for internal (within-company) virality as the main scaling lever, with a concrete expansion example.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable’s virality engine: champions and internal spread
quotes.text: And the magic of Airtable was always seen in its specificity.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A counterintuitive positioning lesson: generic messaging underperforms when product value is unlocked through specific use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable’s virality engine: champions and internal spread
quotes.text: So we knew if we can get to the right people and we can connect the dots to them to the correct use case, so they want to go and evangelize to improve their careers, they will do that both externally and within their companies, and more importantly within the companies, they'll be able to go to their friends and say, "Hey, I'm using Airtable as a content calendar, but you have a UX research problem. And I understand Airtable enough that I can help you build a system. And now I'm a superhero internally because I helped you build this whole new thing. Look at me, I'm amazing."
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: Defines a repeatable virality engine: turn power users into internal “superheroes” by enabling them to translate the tool across adjacent use cases for coworkers.

quotes.topic_title: Airtable’s virality engine: champions and internal spread
quotes.text: In the very early days, what that meant in practice was we literally had a Slack integration that we pulled in a whole bunch of information about anyone who signed up for Airtable, including their title, the company that they worked at, et cetera. And literally would sit there and had a little button in each of the records that came in that would allow us to email them immediately if we had decided that they might be someone we want to talk to.
quotes.speaker: Zoelle Egner
quotes.context: A concrete operational tactic for scaling champion-building: instrument signups with enrichment and rapid outbound to high-potential users.
